facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 264 of 1972 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 264 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 6, 1972 of Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 164 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 6, 1972 of the Bombay High Court at Bombay in Cr. A. No. 164 of 1972.

facts.text: Appellant tried in Court of Session for Greater Bombay for offences under s. 467, s. 471 read with s. 467 and s. 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in this appeal by special leave was tried in the companyrt of Session for Greater Bombay at Bombay for offences under s. 467, under s. 471 read with s. 467 and under S. 420, I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellant ran National Octroi Clearing Agency at Mulund check-post.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution the appellant was running an octroi clearing agency under the name and style of National Octroi Clearing Agency at the Mulund check-post.

facts.text: Appellant attended to transactions for Montgomery Transport Company.

anchor.surface_text: He used to attend to certain transactions relating to the transport companypanies, one of those companypanies being the Montgomery Transport Company.

facts.text: On December 16, 1962, truck MPR 2147 of Montgomery Transport arrived at Mulund check-post carrying Depleix Machine for Imperial Tobacco Company.

anchor.surface_text: On December 16, 1962 a truck belonging to the said transport companypany bearing number MPR 2147 arrived at the check-post carrying a Depleix Machine to be delivered to Messrs Imperial Tobacco Company.

facts.text: Truck had two drivers and one cleaner.

anchor.surface_text: There were two drivers and one cleaner in the truck.

facts.text: Appellant telephoned manager Bakshi of Transport Company to arrange octroi payment over Rs. 8000.

anchor.surface_text: On being approached by them the appellant telephoned to manager Bakshi of the Transport Company to arrange for the payment of octroi which amounted to more than Rs. 8,000/-

facts.text: Bakshi and Director Inderjit Singh obtained Rs. 8196 from Imperial Tobacco Company and handed it to appellant in presence of driver.

anchor.surface_text: The Manager, Bakshi and Director, Inderjit Singh went to the Imperial Tobacco Company the following day and after getting Rs. 8,196/- for the octroi reached the Mulund Check-post. The amount was handed over to the appellant in the presence of the driver.

facts.text: Actual octroi required was Rs. 81.80, Rs. 16 refunded to Imperial Tobacco by cheque.

anchor.surface_text: Actually only Rs. 81-80/- were required for the octroi with the result that Rs. 16/- were paid back to Messrs Imperial Tobacco Company by means of a cheque.

facts.text: During investigation of Pure Drinks Pvt Ltd case, discovered octroi not paid on December 17, 1968 for this transaction.

anchor.surface_text: During the investigation of another case arising out of an alleged forged receipt relating to octroi in respect of some imports by Messrs Pure Drinks Private.Ltd., it came to light that proper octroi had number been- paid on December 17, 1968 in respect of the transaction in question in the present case.

facts.text: Shri Karkhanis and superintendent visited Imperial Tobacco office and found receipt not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Assessor and Collector, Shri Karkhanis, after sending his superintendent Govind Charan to, the office of Messrs Imperial Tobacco Company he himself also visited the Companys office and they both felt that the receipt for the payment of octroi held by the said Company was number genuine.

facts.text: Karkhanis lodged complaint in February 1969 after failing to trace documents.

anchor.surface_text: Having failed to trace the necessary relevant documents in the office files Shri Karkhanis lodged the companyplaint in February, 1969

facts.text: Case registered as 3-L761Sup. CI/73 and appellant committed to Sessions Court after preliminary enquiry under Ch. XVIII Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: and a case 3-L761Sup. CI/73 was registered After preliminary enquiry under Ch. XVIII Cr. P.C. the appellant was companymitted for trial to the companyrt of Session.

facts.text: Trial court held receipt Article A is forged.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that the receipt, Article A is a forged document ? ... 1. In the affirmative.

facts.text: Trial court held not proved that accused forged the receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that it is the accused who forged that receipt with intent to companymit fraud ? ... Not proved.

facts.text: Trial court held accused used forged receipt as genuine knowing it to be forged.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that the accused used this receipt as genuine knowing it to be forged ? ... In the affirmative,

facts.text: Trial court held accused cheated Bombay Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that he cheated the Bombay Municipal Corporation, as alleged ? ... In the affirmative.

facts.text: Trial court held not proved that accused cheated Imperial Tobacco Co.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that the accused cheated the Imperial Tobacco Co. of India Ltd., as alleged ? ... Not proved.

facts.text: Trial court convicted appellant under s.471 r/w 467 IPC with 5 years RI and fine Rs500, and under s.420 IPC with 2 years RI, sentences concurrent.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt thereafter dealt with the, charges of cheating and ultimately companyvicted the appellant for offence under ss. 471 read with 467, I.P.C. and for an offence under s. 420, I.P.C. Under the former he was sentenced to five, years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 500/- ... The substantive sentences were directed to be companycurrent.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed appeal in limine with one word 'Dismissed'.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal to the High Court was dismissed in limine with one word Dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and remanded case to Bombay High Court for rehearing and deciding after recording reasons.

anchor.surface_text: But in the circumstances we have numberoption but, to allow the appeal and remand the case to the High Court for rehearing and deciding the appeal after companysidering the points raised and recording its reasons in accordance with law.

arguments.claim: The receipt Article A is a forged document

anchor.surface_text: According to,the trial court the following points arose for determination Whether it is proved that the receipt, Article A is a forged document ? ... 1. In the affirmative.

arguments.claim: It is not proved that the accused forged the receipt with intent to commit fraud

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that it is the accused who forged that receipt with intent to commit fraud ? ... Not proved.

arguments.claim: The accused used the forged receipt as genuine knowing it to be forged

anchor.surface_text: I do not, however, feel that this earns an acquittal for him The direct charge regarding the forgery could be taken as not proved we will have however to weigh the other evidence for finding out whether he could have used the document which is necessarily a forged docu- ment, as a genuine document. For this purpose we will have to appreciate the evidence of the two witnesses ... It is for this reason that I am feeling that the charge of using a forged receipt knowing it to be forged could be brought home to him.

arguments.qualifiers: I feel, ought to be supposed to be aware

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that he cheated the Bombay Municipal Corporation, as alleged ? ... In the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is proved that the accused cheated the Imperial Tobacco Co. of India Ltd., as alleged ? ... Not proved.

arguments.claim: The High Court was not justified in dismissing the appeal in limine without a speaking order

anchor.surface_text: Before us on appeal by special leave the short point but one of vital importance to the appellant requiring our decision is whether the High Court was justified on the facts and circumstances of this case in unceremoniously dismissing the appeal in limine with one word Dismissed without making a speaking order indicating the reasons for the dismissal.

arguments.claim: The appeal raised arguable and substantial points requiring scrutiny of evidence

anchor.surface_text: The facts briefly stated by us and a close study of the lengthy judgment of the trial court quite clearly show that the appeal in the High Court did raise points which were not only arguable, but were also substantial requiring critical scrutiny and serious appraisal and evaluation of the prosecution evidence and the circumstances of the case.

arguments.claim: High Courts should not summarily dismiss appeals raising arguable points, as per precedent in Mushtak Hussein

anchor.surface_text: The importance of the opinion of the High Court on arguable points requiring consideration on appeal in that court when questions of fact or law are open to challenge by the appellant was emphasised more than 20 years ago by this Court in Mushtak Hussein v. The State of Bombay when Mahajan J., as he then was observed at p. 820 With great respect we are however constrained to observe that it was not right for the High Court to have dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant to that court summarily, as it certainly raised some arguable points which required consideration

arguments.claim: This Court has consistently required High Courts to indicate views in arguable cases

anchor.surface_text: In cases which prima facie raise no arguable issue that course is, of course, justified, but this court would appreciate it if in arguable cases the summary rejection order gives some indication of the views of the High Court on the points raised. ... Since then in a series of decisions quite a number of them reported and several unreported this Court has consistently drawn the attention of the High Courts to the eminent desirability of giving an indication of their views on the points raised in arguable cases

arguments.claim: Recording reasons assists Supreme Court in Article 136 petitions and promotes confidence in judicial process

anchor.surface_text: Without the opinion of the High Court on such points in special leave petitions under article 136 of the Constitution this Court sometimes feels embarrassed if it has to deal with those matters, without the benefit of that opinion. ... Another advantage of recording such reasons is that the accused-appellant who may not always be present in court would have the satisfaction of knowing from the judgment that the points appropriately arising for consideration in his case were actually argued and considered by the High Court while dismissing his appeal. This would, inter alia, tend to promote confidence of the parties concerned in our judicial process.

arguments.claim: Reasons would help counsel decide on further appeal under Art. 136

anchor.surface_text: in the present case had the High Court recorded its reasons for dismissing the appeal it would have better enabled the appellants lawyer to consider the advisibility of appealing under Art. 136 of the Constitution and after filing the appeal would have afforded valuable assistance both to the counsel appearing in this Court and to us in the final disposal of the appeal without feeling the necessity of remanding the case to the High Court for re-hearing.

arguments.claim: Legal position on need for reasons is authoritatively settled by this Court

anchor.surface_text: The legal position on the point in question has been authoritatively settled and declared by this Court and the same has been frequently reiterated in its decisions. The law reports are so full of them that it appears to us to be somewhat surprising that the counsel appearing in the appeal in the High Court should have been unaware of it.

holdings.text: the appeal in the High Court did raise points which were not only arguable, but were also substantial requiring critical scrutiny and serious appraisal and evaluation of the prosecution evidence and the circumstances of the case

anchor.surface_text: The facts briefly stated by us and a close study of the lengthy judgment of the trial court quite clearly show that the appeal in the High Court did raise points which were not only arguable, but were also substantial requiring critical scrutiny and serious appraisal and evaluation of the prosecution evidence and the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Close study of trial court judgment and facts show points needing critical scrutiny of prosecution evidence

holdings.text: The legal position on the point in question has been authoritatively settled and declared by this Court and the same has been frequently reiterated in its decisions

anchor.surface_text: The legal position on the point in question has been authoritatively settled and declared by this Court and the same has been frequently reiterated in its decisions. The law reports are so full of them that it appears to us to be somewhat surprising that the counsel appearing in the appeal in the High Court Should have been unaware of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents like Mushtak Hussein v. State of Bombay and series of decisions require High Courts to indicate views or record reasons when dismissing arguable criminal appeals in limine

holdings.text: allow the appeal and remand the case to the High Court for rehearing and deciding the appeal after considering the points raised and recording its reasons in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: But in the circumstances we have no option but, to allow the appeal and remand the case to the High Court for rehearing and deciding the appeal after considering the points raised and recording its reasons in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court dismissed without reasons despite arguable points and settled law requiring speaking order; remand necessary for proper appraisal and to avoid embarrassment in Art 136 matters

holdings.text: We have taken care not to express any opinion on the merits of the case either way
holdings.reasoning_summary: Remand for High Court to decide merits; SC refrains from commenting

precedents.case_name: Mushtak Hussein v. The State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court should not summarily dismiss appeals raising arguable points without giving some indication of its views on the points raised
precedents.cited_holding: With great respect we are however constrained to observe that it was not right for the High Court to have dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant to that court summarily, as it certainly raised some arguable points which required consideration

precedents.citation: K. K. Jain v. State of Maharashtra 2

anchor.surface_text: In one of the latest decisions of this Court in K. K. Jain v. State of Maharashtra 2  some of the earlier decisions were again noticed and it was considered necessary to repeat the emphasis laid on the necessity of recording reasons by the High Court for dismissing appeals raising questions which cannot be considered to be unsubstantial or not arguable.

precedents.case_name: K. K. Jain v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court must record reasons for dismissing appeals raising questions which cannot be considered unsubstantial or not arguable
